This ( and I know everyone is valid ) is the shit that annoys the fuck out of me , dude your 14 and doing drugs . I‚Äôm 15 and never done drugs in my life , but we‚Äôre both in a similar situation . Except , I didn‚Äôt have a choice in the matter of this and have had it for 9 years with no sign of it ending . All you need to do to lessen the chances of DP DR sticking around is not do drugs . So do the thing that‚Äôll save your sanity and stop doing drugs . And tada your problems will most likely be solved with this disorder . 

Please don‚Äôt throw away your chance of being rid of this disorder just because your young and want to trip . And I‚Äôd suggest never doing drugs again (because now you‚Äôve already experienced dpdr the chances of it coming back with drug use are very high ) 

You do have a choice with this disorder at the moment . So make the right one .

Edit : I‚Äôm sorry if this sounds like I‚Äôm having a go at you , I‚Äôm trying not to , it‚Äôs just your 14 ! Why get into drugs and stuff now ? You‚Äôve got your whole teen hood and early 20s to do dumb shit , but right now , your still a kid . So stop trying to grow up so fast and enjoy being a kid .

The notebook wasn‚Äôt meant to hurt you , that‚Äôs definite . Every parent gets stressed and frustrated when their kids different , because they hate to see their kid being treated differently or being bullied . Parents want their kids to be happy , and they hate to see their kid being upset . She was probably embarrassed for you when you were little , she probably didn‚Äôt like having her own family pointing out that her kids different , because every parent sees their kid as perfect and no parent wants to see their kid suffering . 

And the emails , they were 100% emails looking out for you . She didn‚Äôt want anyone to judge you or upset you so she made sure everyone was aware of your situation so that you could have the most supportive people around you . And she probably didn‚Äôt tell you because she didn‚Äôt want you to feel different from your friends . 

Basically , she loves you and doesn‚Äôt want to see you get hurt . So she‚Äôs trying her best to give you the best start in life without making you feel different .

I googled , I feel like I‚Äôm dreaming all the time , and to no avail . I kept thinking about it though and thought to google it again until I found something . I eventually came across DPDR , I was glad that it was real and that I wasn‚Äôt going mad but I never spoke to anyone about it , accept a friend at the time who didn‚Äôt understand at all . And I haven‚Äôt told anyone apart from a teacher I used to have counselling sessions with and that friend since . The teacher seemed interested but wasn‚Äôt sure and the second time I talked about it she‚Äôd forgotten so I had to go through it again . But yeah , I haven‚Äôt told anyone since . Not even my best friend . I want to tell her soon , I don‚Äôt want secrets . So yeah , I‚Äôm 14 now so I‚Äôve had it without breaks for at least 8 years . I hope it goes away at some point , but I‚Äôm not sure it will . Anyway , I‚Äôm glad you‚Äôve gotten through it ! It gives people like me hope !

Maybe the song has more of a meaning to her ? If she wanted that song to be the last thing she was going to hear maybe it‚Äôs because it meant why she was doing what she was doing or made her feel less guilty about it ? 

I‚Äôm (15 f) and I‚Äôve self harmed and thought about ending it all for multiple years . Hell I‚Äôve even attempted before , well , I more didn‚Äôt care if I survived , and when I did I just kept telling myself it wasn‚Äôt an attempt and I was just in the wrong zone . 

But , and I‚Äôm being completely honest here , it‚Äôs not always the words of he song or poem or whatever , sometimes it‚Äôs the meaning behind it . 

Maybe she likes the album because it makes her feel more understood , or maybe it makes her feel more valid for feeling the way she does . 

The one thing that has always made me feel worse is that I feel like I have no reason to feel shit ( excuse my french ) , it‚Äôs like I have no current reason after everything in my life to feel terrible now . Maybe that‚Äôs similar to how she feels ? 

it‚Äôs not the music that caused the attempt , maybe it didn‚Äôt help  , but it‚Äôs not the sole cause . I know your scared and upset and don‚Äôt know what to do , and I know you probably feel quite helpless . So does she . If I‚Äôm honest , depressing music has been proven to reduce suicide rates , but it also makes you feel more depressed when listening to it . Maybe you two could look for some music that she likes that while it isn‚Äôt depressing also makes her feel better ? I spent three years listening to cringey but horribly depressing songs like silent scream , Bullet , her last words and welcome to my life and every time while I felt worse I also felt calmer . But then I started listening to more artists like Cavetown , Sl√∏tface , Anson Seabra and more songs like ‚Äòall of me‚Äô . 

I can understand completely why you don‚Äôt want her to listen to that album , but to her it must mean more than what it seems to you . To her it meant so much that it was going to be the last thing she was going to hear ,  so go through it with her , try to listen to it with her and try to get her to explain what it means to her . 

I hope this helps and I hope things go well , just let her know from me ( I know I‚Äôm a total stranger and you don‚Äôt have to if you can‚Äôt ) that it is going to be ok , this is the hardest thing to go through and you might feel completely alone , but you only live once , please make the most of it . You can change the world if you want to , the sky is the limit ! ‚ù§Ô∏è

- Hannah ‚ù§Ô∏è

First off , I‚Äôm so sorry for your loss and the fact that now your thinking about what‚Äôs best for your son shows what a great mum you are and how truly caring you are  

For now I think the advice you‚Äôve already got is good , but for when he gets older : 

As he gets older I‚Äôd say that maybe make it normal to talk about his dad , don‚Äôt make it a forbidden topic as he‚Äôll feel like his dad was a bad person . Just talk about him and tell your son what he was like , show him videos of when his dad was happy and make sure your son always opens up about how he‚Äôs feeling about it . And when you talk about your husband to your son , know that it‚Äôs ok to cry , but it‚Äôs also ok to be happy when you think of him . Just don‚Äôt shut the subject of his father away as he grows up as he‚Äôll feel like he won‚Äôt know his full identity . 

I‚Äôd suggest saying something like  ‚Äòdaddy had a illness in his mind that he battled for as long as he could , but he lost his battle‚Äô and when your son asks questions about it , answer them . Perhaps not in the most detailed way nor in the most adult way as it could make your son feel he has to carry guilt about it or look after you because of it , but just in a way that helps him to understand that it‚Äôs no ones fault and that his dad loves him no matter what . 

Maybe when your son gets a little older and wishes he could tell his dad about things , get him to write his dad letters and tie them to balloons and let them go in the sky , this will make him feel connected to his dad even though he can‚Äôt meet his dad . 

It‚Äôs going to be ok , I promise . It‚Äôs ok to cry , it‚Äôs ok to smile , it‚Äôs ok to move on . Just make sure you don‚Äôt forget . I‚Äôm so sorry that your husband lost his battle , and I‚Äôm sorry that you are in this position , but you can still be a great mum 

It‚Äôll be ok , thoughts and prayers ‚ù§Ô∏è
